title: 113_hr3190
content: The "United States Parole Commission Extension Act of 2013" amends the Sentencing Reform Act of 1984 to extend the reference to a "31-year period" instead of a "26-year period." The Act also requires the United States Parole Commission to report on offenders for fiscal years 2012 and 2013 to the Senate and House Committees on the Judiciary. The United States Parole Commission Extension Act of 2013 extends the reference period to 31 years from 26 years. The Commission is required to report on offenders for fiscal years 2012 and 2013 to the Senate and House Committees on the Judiciary. The Commission must provide data on the number of offenders, hearings, record reviews, National Appeals Board considerations, warrants issued and executed, and revocation determinations. The United States Parole Commission Extension Act of 2013 extends the reference period to 31 years from 26 years. The Commission is required to report on offenders for fiscal years 2012 and 2013 to the Senate and House Committees on the Judiciary. The Commission must provide data on the number of offenders, hearings, record reviews, National Appeals Board considerations, warrants issued and executed, and revocation determinations. The Commission also needs to report on the distribution of initial and subsequent offenses, parole rates, and examiner disagreements in each type of case under its jurisdiction. The United States Parole Commission Extension Act of 2013 requires the Commission to report on various aspects of offenders, hearings, appeals, and examiner disagreements in each type of case under its jurisdiction. This includes data on decision guidelines, representation of offenders, administrative appeals, and projected numbers of Federal offenders. The United States Parole Commission Extension Act of 2013 mandates the Commission to report on Federal offenders, annual expenditures, and projected numbers. The Commission must provide this information to the Senate and House Judiciary Committees for each fiscal year. The United States Parole Commission must report the parole failure rate, factors causing it, and remedial measures for the District of Columbia to the Senate and House Judiciary Committees within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The curr_chunk is about the roles of the Speaker of the House of Representatives and the Vice President of the United States as President of the Senate.
